I.  INTRODUCTION  
1.  During the Asian Development Bank (ADB) country programming mission in Manila in 
December 2011, the Government of the People’s Republic of China (PRC) requested ADB to 
provide policy and advisory technical assistance (TA) to help the Gansu provincial government 
(GPG) in improving the legislation and policy support system for eco-compensation in Gansu 
Province.1 This TA was then included in ADB’s country operations business plan, 2012–2014 for 
the  PRC. 2  In  April  2012,  an  ADB  mission  visited  Gansu  Province,  and  reached  an 
understanding with the GPG on the TA impact, outcome, outputs, costs estimates and financing 
plan, implementation arrangements, and consultants’ terms of reference. The TA design and 
monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. The TA builds on achievements of past ADB projects, 
and draws lessons from these TA projects to support  the GPG’s efforts in enhancing the 
provincial eco-compensation legislation and policy framework.  
II.  ISSUES 
2.  The concept of payment for ecosystem services (PES) acknowledges that ecosystem 
can provide benefits to human beings as "ecosystem services."3 Costa Rica, with its 1996 
Forest  Law,  was  the  first  country  to  legally  establish  and  regulate  payments  for  forest 
ecosystem services. Following the adoption of this law, academic attention to the concept of 
PES  and  the  implementation  of  initiatives  designed  to  test  its  basic  premises  increased 
dramatically. The publication in 2005 of the Millennium Ecosystem Assessment—with its main 
findings focused on reversing the degradation of ecosystem services and identifying options to 
enhance them—further developed the theory and practice of PES, and the legal support for its 
implementation.4 
 
3.  PES is a generic name for a variety of arrangements through which the beneficiaries of 
ecosystem  services  pay  the  providers  of  those  services.  There  is  no  generally  accepted 
definition for PES, and the term itself is not used by all who implement the concept. The words 
used in individual countries to translate and describe the concept depend on the language and 
other cultural and political factors.  
 
4.  In the PRC, the traditional approach to ensure the provision of ecosystem services and 
ecological restoration and management has been through eco-compensation payments made 
directly from the government to service providers. Eco-compensation-related mechanisms and 
regulations in the PRC historically have been mainly limited to local areas. However, since 2005, 
the State Council has been giving top priority to, and urging the establishment of, effective 
national eco-compensation mechanisms to support ecological restoration and management. In 
2008, the government stressed the need for an incentive mechanism that will facilitate the 
protection of natural resources such as arable lands, watersheds, forests, grasslands, wetlands, 
and agricultural species resources. A range of eco-compensation programs are now being 
implemented across different provinces in the PRC, including a forest ecological compensation 
fund  and  an  emission  trading  program.  In  a  recent  study,  it  was  noted  that  some  richer 
provinces—Fujian,  Guangdong,  Jiangsu,  Liaoning,  and  Zhejiang—are  where  most  local 
activities  and  innovations  on  eco-compensation  are  happening.  Case  studies  on  poorer

5.  Gansu Province gives high importance to eco-compensation. Along with other sector 
agencies, the Gansu Provincial Forestry Department (GFD) has particularly made efforts to 
include  eco-compensation  mechanisms  in  its  policies  and  regulatory  framework.  Several 
regulations related to eco-compensation have been issued at three different levels, i.e., local 
regulations,  governmental  management  measures,  and  official  documents  issued  by  the 
provincial government. There are six different rules and regulations related to eco-compensation: 
(i) implementation solutions to the forest law, (ii) ordinance for the protection of the Qilian 
Mountain Nature Reserve, (iii) ordinance on grasslands of Gansu Province, (iv) ordinance on 
forest  ecological  and  environmental  protection  of  Gansu  Province,  (v)  ordinance  for  water 
resources  management  in  the  Shiyang  River  basin,  and  (vi)  ordinance  on  ecological  and 
environmental protection in oil exploration and exploitation. 
 
6.  Despite the existence of these legal provisions to deal with eco-compensation, the main 
challenges which remain are that the existing principles and legal provisions are too general, 
and lack clarity on the operations of the existing legal provisions. This TA will build on the 
experiences and lessons learnt from the various ongoing and recently completed initiatives on 
eco-compensation in the PRC and also the assessment on the provincial legislative, regulatory, 
and  policy  framework  that  was  conducted  under  the  PRC–Global  Environment  Facility 
Partnership on Land Degradation in Dryland Ecosystems.6 The proposed plan for an improved 
legal  and  policy  framework  and  enhanced  capacity  for  implementing  eco-compensation 
mechanisms resulting from this TA will contribute to improving environmental sustainability in 
Gansu Province. 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
7.  The TA will support the GPG’s effort in enhancing the provincial eco-compensation 
legislation  and  policy  framework.  The  expected  impact  of  the  TA  will  be  enhanced 
environmental sustainability in Gansu Province. The expected outcome of the TA will be an 
improved legislative framework for eco-compensation in Gansu Province. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
8.  Output 1: Eco-compensation approaches for forests and grasslands. The TA will 
review existing methodologies used for assessment of forest and grassland ecosystem services 
in the PRC and other countries, and provide recommendations on development of appropriate 
methodologies for Gansu Province. Rapid assessments will be conducted through pilot studies 
in selected forest and grassland sites to capture broader ecosystems services provided and 
implications for water resources management and associated issues. The results of these

studies will contribute to the recommendations for the improved eco-compensation legislation in 
output 2. Specific suboutputs and activities will include 
(i)  review of existing methodologies for estimating forest and grassland ecosystem 
services, and recommendations for an approach to be developed for Gansu 
Province; 
(ii)  rapid assessment of ecosystem services, and key economic values of forests 
and grasslands in Gansu Province through selection of two pilot study areas;7 
and 
(iii)  formulation of recommendations on eco-compensation approaches and rates for 
forests  and  grasslands  considering  the  wider  ecosystem  services; 8  and 
implications  on  water  resources  management  and  the  current  land  use  and 
management approaches, including protection regimes and its implications. 
9.  Output 2: Recommendations for mainstreaming eco-compensation into relevant 
legislation. Specific suboutputs and activities will include 
(i)  a review of international legal, institutional, and policy frameworks supporting 
forest- and grassland-related eco-compensation;  
(ii)  a  national  review,  including  successes  in  other  provinces,  of  legislation  and 
policies,  and  other  provincial  policies  for  forest-  and  grassland-related  eco-
compensation; 
(iii)  a Gansu provincial review of relevant legislation (i.e., specifically the three levels 
of  provincial  legislation)  and  policies  for  forest-  and  grassland-related  eco-
compensation; 
(iv)  a comprehensive report with recommendations on specific amendments required 
to provincial legislation to incorporate improved eco-compensation mechanisms; 
these  recommendations  will  specifically  focus  on  revising  the  document  on 
implementation  measures  for  the  forest  law,  especially  those  related  to 
increasing additional provisions related to eco-compensation; 
(v)  preparation  of  recommendations  for  inclusion  of  eco-compensation-related 
mechanisms for the Qilian Mountain Nature Reserve’s rules that were issued by 
the Gansu People’s Congress by proposing revisions to the rules which are 
specifically related to eco-compensation; 
(vi)  preparation of draft legislation—with emphasis on eco-compensation—for the 
management  of  grasslands  related  to  balancing  grazing  activities  against 
conservation and establishing areas that are off-limits to grazing activities; and 
(vii)  a  policy  brief  as  a  knowledge  product  for  an  improved  eco-compensation 
legislation and policy framework in Gansu Province.  
10.  Output 3: Enhanced institutional capacity on eco-compensation of forests and 
grasslands. Specific suboutputs and activities will include 
(i)  development of training and awareness-raising materials for key stakeholders;9

explore inclusion of carbon trading as an instrument for eco-compensation.

workshop, an international study tour,10 and several grassroots-level workshops 
and awareness-raising seminars; and 
(iii)  preparation of a glossy information booklet on eco-compensation mechanisms 
and approaches in Gansu Province for sustainable management of forests and 
grasslands. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
11.  The TA is estimated to cost $500,000, of which $400,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF–other sources).  
 
12.  The government will provide counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff, office 
space, office supplies, domestic transportation, workshop costs, administrative support, and 
other in-kind contributions. The cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
13.  The TA will be implemented over 18 months from 1 November 2012 to 30 April 2014. 
The Gansu Provincial Finance Bureau (GFB) will be the executing agency. The director of the 
International Division of the GFB will be the focal point within the executing agency. The GFD 
will be the implementing agency. The Global Environment Facility Office under the GFD will 
function as the TA management office to coordinate day-to-day TA operations. A full-time 
project  officer  will  be  recruited  by  the  GFD  to  serve  as  the  overall  manager  of  the  TA 
responsible  for  coordination  matters  among  ADB,  consultants,  and  related  government 
agencies. 
 
14.  A steering committee will be established to provide guidance on TA implementation 
issues and ensuring interagency coordination. The steering committee will be chaired by the 
deputy director general of the GFB and will be represented by relevant directors from the Gansu 
People’s Congress, the GPG’s Legislation Office, the Gansu Provincial Agriculture and Animal 
Husbandry Department, the Gansu Provincial Water Resources Department, the GFB, and the 
GFD. The steering committee will meet on a quarterly basis. The GFD will provide in-kind 
counterpart  staff,  office  space,  office  supplies,  domestic  transportation,  workshop  costs, 
administrative support, and other in-kind contributions. 
 
15.  It  is  estimated  that  the  TA  will  require  6  person-months  of  international  consulting 
services and 24 person-months of national consulting services. Five national consultants (TA 
team  leader  and  eco-compensation  legal  and  institutional  specialist,  a  forestry  eco-
compensation  specialist,  a  grassland  eco-compensation  specialist,  a  training  and  capacity 
development specialist, and an environmental economist) and two international consultants (an 
environmental legislation and policy specialist, and an environmental economist) will be required 
for the TA implementation. The consultants will be engaged by ADB through a firm following 
ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time) using the 
quality- and cost-based selection method, with a quality–cost weighing ratio of 80:20. The 
biodata technical proposal approach will be used. Equipment will be procured following ADB’s 
Procurement Guidelines (2010, as amended from time to time), and will be handed over to the 
GPG upon completion of the proposed TA. Operational expenses for trainings, workshops,

IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
16.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $400,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of the People’s Republic of China for Building a Framework for Regulation and 
Policy Support System for Eco-Compensation in Gansu, and hereby reports this action to the 
Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
A.  Introduction 
1.  The consultants will be engaged by the Asian Development Bank (ADB) through a firm 
following ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time) 
using the quality- and cost-based selection method, with a quality–cost weighing ratio of 80:20. 
It is estimated that the technical assistance (TA) will require 6 person-months of international 
consulting services and 24 person-months of national consulting services.   
 
B.  Terms of Reference 
2.  Environmental legislation and policy specialist (international, 3 person-months). The 
specialist with knowledge of eco-compensation will support the national TA team leader. The 
specialist will have (i) an advanced university degree in environmental policy, with at least 10 
years of relevant experience; (ii) basic understanding of the environmental legal system in the 
People’s Republic of China (PRC) and eco-compensation-related legislation; (iii) experience in 
and understanding of environmental issues with on-the-ground working experience in the PRC; 
and (iv) demonstrated experience in similar assignments. The specialist will have the following 
specific responsibilities: 
(i)  work with the national TA team leader to refine the overall study framework; 
scope of pilot studies; and outlines of the inception, interim, and final TA reports;  
(ii)  conduct  an  international  review  of  legal,  institutional,  and  policy  frameworks 
supporting forest and grassland management related to eco-compensation; 
(iii)  identify appropriate agencies and organizations in the target countries for the 
foreign legislation review mission, and liaise with agencies and organizations 
regarding the mission program;  
(iv)  participate in the preparation of (a) a draft recommendation for the inclusion of 
eco-compensation-related mechanisms for the Qilian Mountain Nature Reserve’s 
rules, and implementation measures for the forest law; and (b) draft legislation—
with emphasis on eco-compensation—for management of grasslands related to 
balancing grazing activities against conservation and establishing areas that are 
off-limits to grazing activities;  
(v)  support the national TA team leader in consolidating the inputs from specialists 
who will carry out (a) a review of existing methodologies used for the assessment 
of forest and grassland ecosystem services; (b) pilot studies; and (c) a review of 
existing legal, institutional, and policy frameworks for eco-compensation related 
to forest and grassland management; 
(vi)  contribute to drafting and reviewing the inception, interim, and final TA reports; 
(vii)  prepare  a  policy  brief  (knowledge  product)  with  recommendations  for  an 
improved eco-compensation legislation and policy framework in Gansu Province;   
(viii)  participate in project workshops (i.e., inception, midterm, and final workshops) 
and other seminars presenting the TA results; and  
(ix)  provide input into other related technical tasks as requested by the national TA 
team leader. 
 
3.  Environmental  economist  (international,  3  person-months).  The  environmental 
economist will support the national TA team leader and will have (i) an advanced university 
degree in environmental economics, with at least 10 years of relevant experience; (ii) a sound 
understanding  of  the  eco-compensation  approaches  in  the  PRC;  (iii)  experience  in  and 
understanding of payment for ecosystem services and eco-compensation issues, with on-the-

(i)  review existing international methodologies used for assessment of forest and 
grassland ecosystem services, and provide a review report;  
(ii)  establish  estimate  for  current  value  of  ecosystem  services  of  forests  and 
grasslands in Gansu Province based on existing literature;  
(iii)  provide recommendations on the development of appropriate methodologies for 
assessing forest and grassland ecosystem services in Gansu Province;  
(iv)  review existing successful international eco-compensation approaches and rates 
for forests and grasslands, and give recommendations for (a) inclusion of eco-
compensation-related  mechanisms  for  the  Qilian  Mountain  Nature  Reserve’s 
rules; (b) implementation measures for the forest law; and (c) draft legislation—
with emphasis on eco-compensation—for management of grasslands related to 
balancing grazing activities against conservation and establishing areas that are 
off-limits to grazing activities; 
(v)  support the international legislation and policy specialist in preparing a policy 
brief as a knowledge product for an improved eco-compensation legislation and 
policy framework in Gansu Province; 
(vi)  give presentations at workshops and seminars; and 
(vii)  provide input into other related technical tasks as requested by the national TA 
team leader. 
 
4.  Eco-compensation legal and institutional specialist and technical assistance team 
leader (national, 7 person-months). The specialist will be responsible for overall coordination 
and supervision of the TA activities and outputs, and day-to-day liaison with the executing and 
implementing agencies as well as with other national government agencies supporting the 
related work. The specialist will have (i) an advanced university degree in environmental, legal, 
institutional, or policy issues, with at least 10 years of relevant experience; (ii) a sound basic 
understanding of the environmental legal system in the PRC and eco-compensation-related 
legislation; (iii) experience and understanding in payment for ecosystem services and eco-
compensation issues with on-the-ground working experience in the PRC; and (iv) demonstrated 
experience in similar assignments with international organizations. The specialist will have the 
following specific responsibilities: 
(i)  develop the overall detailed study framework, and draft the TA inception, midterm, 
and final reports along with the international environmental legislation and policy 
specialist;  
(ii)  review and coordinate pilot studies and organize workshops;  
(iii)  function as the leading expert on the national review, including successes in 
other  provinces,  on  legislation  and  policies,  and  other  provincial  policies  on 
forest- and grassland-related eco-compensation;  
(iv)  ensure that the legal and institutional review and key recommendations build 
upon the work done on past legal and institutional reviews conducted under the 
PRC–Global Environment Facility Partnership on Land Degradation in Dryland 
Ecosystems;  
(v)  provide a comprehensive report with recommendations on specific amendments 
required  to  provincial  legislation  to  incorporate  improved  eco-compensation 
mechanisms; 
(vi)  prepare  recommendations  for  inclusion  of  eco-compensation-related 
mechanisms for the Qilian Mountain Nature Reserve’s rules; 
(vii)  prepare draft legislation—with emphasis on eco-compensation—for management 
of grasslands related to balancing grazing activities against conservation and 
establishing areas that are off-limits to grazing activities;

Appendix 3  13 
(iv)  support the national TA team leader in providing a comprehensive report, with 
recommendations on specific amendments required for provincial legislation to 
incorporate improved eco-compensation mechanisms; 
(v)  participate in workshops and seminars, and present study results from the forest-
related eco-compensation pilot projects; and 
(vi)  provide input into other related technical tasks as requested by the national TA 
team leader. 
 
7.  Grassland eco-compensation specialist (national, 4 person-months). The specialist 
will support the national environmental economist and will have (i) an advanced university 
degree in environmental economics, with at least 5 years of relevant experience; (ii) a good 
understanding of environmental issues in the PRC and grassland-related eco-compensation 
issues and approaches; and (iii) demonstrated experience in similar assignments. The specialist 
will have the following specific responsibilities: 
(i)  support the national environmental economist in implementing the pilot studies 
and  conducting  the  review  of  existing  methodology  for  assessing  grassland 
ecosystem services; 
(ii)  provide individual review reports on compensation rate, payment vehicles, and 
compensation mechanisms for grassland-related eco-compensation; 
(iii)  participate in the TA inception, midterm, and final workshops, and provide inputs 
needed for the preparation of TA inception, midterm, and final reports; 
(iv)  support the national TA team leader in providing a comprehensive report with 
recommendations on specific amendments required for provincial legislation to 
incorporate improved eco-compensation mechanisms; 
(v)  participate  in  workshops  and  seminars,  and  present  study  results  in  the 
respective study areas; and 
(vi)  provide input into other related technical tasks as requested by the national TA 
team leader. 
 
8.  Training  and  capacity  development  specialist  (national,  3  person-months).  The 
specialist will have (i) an advanced university degree in environmental or social sciences, with at 
least 5 years of relevant experience; (ii) a good understanding of environmental issues in the 
PRC, and the development and implementation of environment-related training programs; and 
(iii) demonstrated experience in the development of training materials and implementation of 
training programs at various levels. The specialist will have the following specific responsibilities: 
(i)  organize workshops and seminars, 
(ii)  develop training materials, 
(iii)  provide reports on trainings or workshops, and 
(iv)  provide input into other related technical tasks as requested by the national TA 
team leader. 
 
9.  The consultants will submit the following reports: (i) an inception report within a month 
after mobilization, (ii) an interim report 7 months after the TA starts, (iii) a draft final report 15 
months after the TA starts, (iv) a final report at the conclusion of the TA, and (v) a knowledge 
product. The final report will reflect comments made by ADB, the government agencies, and 
other  relevant  parties.  The  consultants  will  submit  all  reports  in  English  and  Chinese 
languages—six copies each in English and Chinese to the government, and three copies of the 
English version to ADB, including an electronic copy on CD-ROM. The reports will be published 
in  Chinese  and  English  languages,  and  posted  on  the  websites  of  ADB  and  the  Gansu 
provincial government.
